Title: OILY SUBSTANCE ON BOOK AND COVER
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2024
Body: I ordered a new book and it came with an oily substance all over cover and outer part of book.

Title: overstuffed
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2024
Body: How did this get to be a bestseller?  It was a soap opera.  Unnecessary exposition.  Not enough character development to make you care about what happened.

Title: For the life of me‚Ä¶
Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2023
Body: I can‚Äôt even believe this book was published.  This is probably the worst writing I have ever experienced.  This author should teach ‚Äútell‚Äù writing versus ‚Äúshow‚Äù writing.  This book should be used by English teachers worldwide on how NOT to write.  The author decides how the readers will collectively feel and react to the characters and their insipid, incomprehensible actions and thoughts.  No character can be differentiated from another except by the author telling the reader obscure facts that lend no depth or interest to any of them.  A remarkable failure.

Title: Boring
Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2024
Body: This was one of the worst books I‚Äôve ever read‚Ä¶. So many glowing reviews! I kept reading and reading waiting for it to develop‚Ä¶. I would even be embarrassed to give to someone. I‚Äôm only giving 1 star because I must. In the positive, the book arrived in time.

Title: Clunky and awkward
Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2023
Body: It seemed that the author was trying too hard, like a bad singer trying to reach a high note. Another reviewer said all tell, no show and I agree. The only reason I stuck with it was because it seemed interesting at first and I almost never abandon a book.

Title: Written for an adolescent
Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2023
Body: I rarely abandon a book but I could not get beyond the first few chapters.  I felt like I was reading a YA book. Boring, flat, trite characters. Simplistic bland writing style. Not worth the money.

Title: "Oprah, you're not making sense to me this time.
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2023
Body: I read the book cover to cover.Personally, I found the characters to be flat and the dialogue predictable. The storylines were familiar.Each of the characters followed a familiar line of shallow development.Even the "let's wrap this book up" ending was laid out with out fanfare.I kept waiting for the "wow factor," or the "I didn't see that coming," but it never developed; nothing like that occurred.For me, every aspect of the book was flat.The hype around this book alludes me.  I cannot figure it out."Oprah, you're not making sense to me this time."

Title: Terrible writing, meh story
Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2023
Body: Awful characters. I didn‚Äôt care about any of them. None of them grew at all or dealt with their problems with one or two exceptions. So many cliches. Writing was forgettably mediocre. Where were the editors? Why in the world was it so long and did the perspectives and time period change with every chapter. Served no purpose. Had to read for book club, or wouldn‚Äôt have finished.

Title: Boring Book
Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2024
Body: This was probably one of the most boring and slow moving books that I have ever read.  Waste of money.

Title: Hello, beautiful!
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2023
Body: HELLO BEAUTIFULAnn NapolitanoWhen I turned my eBook to page one, I said aloud ‚ÄúHELLO, BEAUTIFUL!‚ÄùI knew from page one that I was in for a good time what I did not know was how much I‚Äôd enjoy this book and the process of reading it and I certainly didn‚Äôt know I had found a new favorite author.In Hello Beautiful we start with William. William was born to a family suffering a great loss. And even in the first few pages with William, we come to know him in all that he isn‚Äôt instead of what he is. It‚Äôs an interesting way to construct a character.In the next chapter, we meet Julia and all that she is and all that she has. She is a lot, has a lot. Specifically, things that William does not. She has a close, loving family, and she has a plan and the will to carry it out.William and Julia meet in college and begin a wonderful life together. We follow over the years as eventually, William's past comes to light and the very thing that drew them together threatens to tear them apart.I read this one towards the end of 2022 and had to hold onto this review for over six months. It was torture. It was one of the best books I read last year, and I can‚Äôt wait for you to read it. It would make a great book club selection as there would be a lot to discuss. I imagine readers on opposing sides of imaginary lines, arguing their point. And they would both be right. That is the beauty of this book.Let‚Äôs talk about what I especially liked about it.The first thing I loved and noticed was the sentence structure. There is a pattern to the structure that creates a rhythm that increases reading enjoyment. Essentially it is very easy to read.The second thing I loved is what I noted previously. I loved how William was constructed as a character. His pages felt vacuous. As if I were leaving a part of myself there with him on every page. There is a scene early on when William is describing a moment with a professor. That passage is so telling of William and his lens for seeing his world and interacting with it.The third thing I loved was the number of emotions that were stirred within me. I don‚Äôt remember the last time I was angry with a fictional character. It‚Äôs been six months and I still disagree with some of the characters' choices.Although this was a five-star read for me I do want to note how critical the writing is. These characters are beautifully imperfect, and the narrative, no matter the character, was severe in correction. This can lead to a lack of empathy toward the characters and their situation. It didn‚Äôt affect me much, but I think readers should be aware of that going in.HELLO BEAUTIFUL comes out on March 14, 2023, and I highly recommend it.Now an Oprah Book Club pick for March 2023HELLO BEAUTIFUL‚Ä¶‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏èThanks to Random House Publishing Group - Random House, The Dial Press for the advanced copy!

Title: A very thoughtful book
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2024
Body: This is a different kind of read for me but it kept my attention from the beginning. The characters are very deep and well developed. The way the author explains their thoughts and feelings is magnificent! The characters evolve, with all of their flaws and choices as part of who they are, making them the people they become. The depth of the family connection plays such a part in who they are and the author explains this in a comprehensive way, making the story come full circle. It‚Äôs a story of real people who make real choices, right or wrong, based on their own beliefs. Five stars!

Title: Beatiful!
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2024
Body: I never review books but this story is a rarity. I loved every word and it is so beautifully written, I didn't want it to end. It will be on my list of top 5 favorite books.

Title: Beautifully written
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2024
Body: One of my favorite reads in a long time and excited to have found a new author! Definitely recommend!

Title: Page Turner
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2024
Body: This is an excellent read.

Title: I haven‚Äôt cried in so long!
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2024
Body: So good! Well written and heart felt. I felt like I could picture the different characters.Definitely a worthwhile read!

Title: Sad and Beautiful
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2024
Body: Hello Beautiful is sad and beautiful at the same time. Throughout the twists and turns, love is the recurring theme. Family is also a theme, as it weaves itself through the years and back again. A thoughtful and mindful book. Excellent for Bookclubs.

Title: My new favorite!
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2024
Body: I love this book so much. I couldn't stop reading & I feel sad that it's over. I felt so close to all of the characters & their journeys. I admire all of them & I'm going to miss them terribly.

Title: Beautiful Story
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2024
Body: At the beginning, I would set the book aside and I think it was because I could feel the heaviness of the words which were to come. Then I couldn‚Äôt read it fast enough and I didn‚Äôt want the book to end. It‚Äôs a story of family, love, loss and forgiveness. ‚ÄúHello Beautiful‚Äù

Title: required. reading for sisters
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2024
Body: I‚Äôm amazed that anyone can capture the essence of sisterhood.  As I read this book I saw my sisters weaving in and out.  Lovely

Title: So Disappointing
Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2024
Body: I almost never give up on a book, but this author has zero ability to accuratelydescribe setting. I can understand why she literally had to write the dates at the beginning of every chapter because the setting didn‚Äôt in any way reflect the time period.In 1997, Alice and her friend were singing along to records? Really? They didn‚Äôt have CDs? Was the author alive in 1997?When Alice is in college in the early 2000s and searches for her aunt‚Äôs artwork, the author doesn‚Äôt even mention the internet. I understand not dwelling on it, but surely there are relevant implications about the ease of uncovering secrets in a world that is suddenly so much more connected than it has ever been before.Ultimately I gave up after the Alice chapter that ends in 2003. You mean to tell me in 2001, Alice is in Boston, and her mother is in New York, and the author was in no way compelled to even mention 9/11? At all? Wouldn‚Äôt that have been a very real driver for the sisters to contact Julia to maybe, I don‚Äôt know, find out if she was even alive? Or did they just shrug and sit around hoping for another postcard?The next chapter skips to 2008, and I don‚Äôt see any point in continuing. Maybe this book is set in an alternate reality version of the 1980s-2000s that never evolved beyond the 1950s, but I can‚Äôt suspend my disbelief enough to make this book believable.Oprah failed me this time.

Title: shallow and pseudo
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2024
Body: I really disliked this book.  None of the family relationships were believable.  Many scenes that were supposed to be pivotal had no depth and little meaning.  For example: William and Sylvia on a bench.  What happened?  She was sad.  He was sad.  I had to go back and reread this scene.  Nothing.  The author's writing style is terrible - full of pseudo psychology.  And her work is sprinkled with absurd metaphors.  Example: The sisters have avoided touching  because "It was the bumpers on the strange bowling alley they were playing within".

Title: Can't Believe This Was An Oprah Pick
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2024
Body: I was really disappointed in this book.  I picked it because I enjoyed Dear Edward and I am a fan of Oprah's book club.  Unfortunately, not this time.  I did not think the characters were developed at all and I was rolling my eyes at some of the thoughts and unbelievable things in the characters lives that were never developed.  As far as William's childhood I could understand why his parents were traumatized by the loss but it sounds like William raised himself. Really?? They never heard from them again after they didn't go to the wedding and just sent a check??  I could go on and on by the loose ends in this novel.  I finished it but really couldn't wait for it to end.

Title: terrible book with a simple non developed story
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2024
Body: The story wants to imitate "little women" where tragedy struck a family. There is no development of characters or actual engaging quality story to follow.If you like quality writing and not the typical airport style reading this is not your book.

Title: I don't get it
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 13, 2024
Body: I don't understand the popularity of this book or how it gets so highly reviewed. It started out well but then turned into some modern version of Little Women. Full disclosure, I only read about 20% so maybe it gets better.

Title: Mediocre prose and bad characters
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2024
Body: Somehow manages to be a prime example of both men writing women and women writing men. Can‚Äôt go ten pages without mentioning the 6ft 7 brooding man or the heavy breasts of the heroine. Bored out of my mind within the first 6 pages and struggled to finish the book. Not remotely realistic (this genre is supposed to be realistic). Straight into the dustbin

Title: Not worth the time
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2024
Body: I didn't like the tone of the book - depressive, hopeless, indifferent, empty. I read 45% of the book hoping that it would get better and it didn't. Also, the characters didn't develop and it was hard to connect to anyone.

Title: Superficial and a waste of time
Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2024
Body: I am shocked that this book has received such great reviews.  It reads as if it was written by a teenager.  The plot is banal, the writing is overly sentimental and repetitive, and the story is just plain scholck.  I managed to read until page 220 and then I just had to quit.  The characters lack any depth and you just don't really care about any of it by midway through the book.

Title: Uncreative story
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2024
Body: Tedious reading,  boring story line,  trendy topics.  I read the first several chapters and then the last one to find out  how it ended.

Title: Stuck this one out...
Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2024
Body: Sorry to give a negative review but I did not find this book remotely enjoyable. Shallow characters to match the shallow storyline which was painfully dragged out. Repetitive and rambling. Quite surprised this was one of Oprah's picks.

Title: Disappointed ---characters simply not authentic
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2023
Body: I bought hardcover & Kindle editions on day of release after seeing Oprah rave about it on CBS. What I appreciate most with Oprah's fiction picks is the selections tend to be a cut above (i.e. more literature) than morning show or other celeb book clubs. (I esp enjoyed Oprah's early picks back in late 90s.) I'm sad to report this was a big miss for me. Having been raised with 4 sisters in blue-collar Chicago, I thought it'd be a slam dunk, but I went from being underwhelmed to disappointed to annoyed. Pains me to write a mediocre review as author likely poured her heart and soul into it, but imo this book needed another year editing and revising, as this just wasn't there yet. A few specifics:* I applaud author for attempting to give characters depth & complexity but she violated basic rule of show, don't tell. Too much of the characters' personalities were explained with excess exposition but not SHOWN to readers through actions or dialogue.* While I don't adhere that authors should write only what they know, it was obvious to me early on the author didn't grow up with sisters, nor grow up or spend years in Pilsen or blue-collar Chicago. Neither felt authentic. Felt more as if author was on outside observing or imagining versus having lived it. I can overlook some tells, but the more those slips/omissions/errors add up, the more a reader loses faith in the entire story.*William's upbringing also didn't ring true. I can understand grief-stricken parents emotionally absent in a child's life, but not to the degree explained (not shown) in the book. More development and examples were needed, as parents cannot simply ignore a child--they still need to nurse, feed, cloth and shelter, etc. It's easy to tell but author needed to again SHOW us how cold parents can be there, but not present.* On plus side, the story & writing comes most alive to me with passages on basketball--the relationships, the tempo, the love of the game, the history. Here's where the author did her homework and really did a nice job translating it, esp to female readership (not to sound sexist, as I'm a woman who played basketball in her youth but still learned a few things or two and appreciated the insights she brought.)I'll leave it there as I don't mean to tear down a book that's not horrible, just not great. Possibly my disappointment is greater than most because I came up with high expectations and this just wasn't credible for me. As other reviewers noted, it's not a bad beach read, but not literature and not Oprah-caliber.  (Sorry for any typos--please don't review my review lol.)

Title: Would make a better movie
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2024
Body: Not sure how to even review this book. I thought it drawn out and am not even sure I liked the characters all that much. Julia never knew about her husband‚Äôs past? The mother, Rose, wasn‚Äôt much better. Don‚Äôt want to give it away but I wasn‚Äôt impressed for a book that got so much hype. Liked Crawdads much more. Would not rave about this book, but, like I said, it might work as a movie or mini series. I found the writing tedious and slow, and had to skip a few sentences here and there.

Title: Typical Family Story
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2024
Body: This story wasn't remarkable or so different than the dysfunctional families we're all apart of in some way. We can all see some of own story in this multigenerational where hidden family secrets come out in the light and people pretend nothing happened because their pride won't allow them to apologize. While I was invested in the story because it was a read for my book club, I would have never picked this on my own. I like that the author switches perspectives as it covers various decades but overall it's just another family drama.

Title: I find this a tedious read
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2024
Body: I'm about 3/4 of the way through the book and have thought about putting it down several times. To me there are too many characters the author is trying to develop without much plot. I'll probably finish it and maybe I'll change my mind but . . .

Title: I don‚Äôt understand the hype
Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2023
Body: Hello Beautiful by Ann NapolitanoHello Beautiful centers around the Padavano sisters, and a man named William. Like the classic Little Women, we are intertwined into the sisters‚Äô close-knit family, and we bear witness to their life‚Äôs highlights, but more so their downfalls. Oddly, as close as the sisters are displayed to the reader, we see very little in the way of communication between the four of them.There are marriages, births, loves and losses stretched across thirty-some-odd years. There is a beautifully storied first half, engulfing the reader. The middle of our story is lackluster though and a bit drawn out and I found myself uninterested.The last quarter of the book felt rushed to me like the author knew she had to wrap up the story. One character, in particular, I didn‚Äôt understand at all. She‚Äôs in her early 20s but does not have the inquisitive nature of an early twenty-something. This leads to my disappointment with this character. We have a very unfinished reunion at the very end, and unless there is going to be a sequel, leaves a lot of questions.I know this book is beloved by so many, and I did enjoy it, don‚Äôt get me wrong. I think it was hyped so much that I expected to give it a perfect five-star rating. I‚Äôm going to give Hello Beautiful three out of five stars. It was good, but had the potential to be great.

Title: Just ok.
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 29, 2024
Body: Like other readers I found it a frustratingly long and tedious read with little wow. I felt a long time was spent saying very little. Too many holes as well in storylines that were started and either never ended or just let underdeveloped halfway.  Although the book kept trying to emphasize how close the sisters were , it‚Äôs really not reflected in the book.I did like  that it touched on some real subject matter like being a single parent, depression and mental health etc.I know lots of people seem to love it but I just couldn‚Äôt get into it.

Title: An absorbing but disappointing read
Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2024
Body: I can see why this book is so popular. It immediately sucks you in with the first sentence. But as I read on and finished it, I had more criticisms than compliments. The characters are very one-dimensional. You get caricatures more than characters that have real depth. For example, Julia is the "planner." Cecilia is the "artist." And so on. The family dynamic portrayed throughout is sweet but highly unbelievable. I think that I was just expecting more from this one and left feeling disappointed.

Title: Not sure I understand the hype
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2024
Body: Decent story line.  Flew through the years a bit too quickly.  Never felt a bond with any of the characters.  Just ‚Äúok.‚Äù

Title: Arrived damaged
Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2024
Body: Haven‚Äôt read the book- assuming the content is great. I bought two books, one for my friends birthday and another for myself and once of the books came with the pages damaged in the front. One of them is torn into the words. It‚Äôs not a big deal I can read around, but assuming I only order one and it came like that for a gift would suck.

Title: Not Believable
Date: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2023
Body: I am giving this book three stars only because I really appreciated Ann Napolitano's book A Good Hard Look, which influenced me to read Flannery O'conner.  I really wanted to like Hello Beautiful, but it was just too unbelievable.  There were hardly any likable characters, with the possible exception of William's basketball friends  It reads more like a soap opera than serious fiction.  For example, in what world other than soap opera can a widow who lives in a blue collar area and whose husband is described as having low paying jobs suddenly be able to move to Miami and hobnob with the wealthy?  How does she support herself?  We aren't told anything other than that she has wealthy friends.  In what world can a recent college graduate with a new baby be able to move to Manhattan (much less the upper east side) and afford childcare , housing, and expensive  clothes while doing research for a college professor?  Huh?  Sounds like fantasy.  And anyone who thinks Hello, Beautiful resembles Little Women obviously hasn't read the book.  The only similarity is that both books are about four sisters.  Can anyone imagine Marmie abandoning her children or not speaking to one of her daughters and granddaughters?  Really?  I had to force myself to finish this book.  As others have said, it was  depressing, peopled with unloving , unloveable , and unbelievable characters.

Title: Beautifully written‚Ä¶
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2024
Body: I love this story about the four Padavano sisters and their parents. Rose is the strong willed matriarch of the family. She strongly believes her husband, Charlie, just doesn‚Äôt quite measure up to what he could have been. Together, they have four daughters. Readers are drawn right into this story and feel every emotion the characters experience. Julie, the eldest of the four sisters, is a planner, a fixer, a girl who knows what she wants and knows how to get it. She has a plan for her life and it doesn‚Äôt include living in a tiny house like where she was raised. Second daughter is quiet Sylvie, a reader who has worked in the public library since she was thirteen and sneaks kisses from the boys behind the shelves knowing she doesn‚Äôt want a boyfriend. She doesn‚Äôt  take the boys seriously because she is just practicing for her one true love. The twins who are energetic, fun loving girls, round out the Padavano sisters. Then there is William a loner, ignored and never loved at home, socially awkward, always wondering where he fits in, how should he behave, and why he wasn‚Äôt enough for his parents. He only feels at home on the basketball court. Julie has decided William is just what she needs to get her life plan started. In alternating chapters, the four main characters tell their story with each chapter bearing the character‚Äôs name. Quoting Walt Whitman‚Äôs poetry and making comparisons of the four sisters to the sisters in Little Women by Alcott, this book is more than a family saga. This book is a love story. It is about acceptance, heartbreak, forgiveness, and understanding.  Napolitano‚Äôs writing is thoughtful and beautiful. The story is deeply moving as each character grows and discover his or her truth and learns how powerful it is to live an authentic life. A five star read and on my list of favorite books in 2024!

Title: Hello beautiful
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2024
Body: It's not very often that I cry reading a book but this book was so beautifully written I could feel the sadness, the love, everyone's emotions, and I was moved to tears. What a beautiful and sometimes sad story but well worth every word!

Title: so well done!
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2024
Body: Such an amazing story about how real families love and feud.  I loved the perspective of each character that carried the story forward.  I also loved the intrinsic bonds that bind a family regardless of decades and perceived wrongs.

Title: delightful
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2024
Body: To read about and get to know the characters who comprise a large and encompassing Italian family and their friends. This book can renew your faith in humankind and will- at the end, put a smile on your face.

Title: A.story of family
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2024
Body: Ann Napolitano knows how to weave a story , but even more impressive is her ability to make you love her characters.  She develops them so completely, you think you know them, their motivations, and what they will think and do next.  The title is very accurate, as each character is beautiful through the eyes of those who love them.  Highly recommend!!

Title: One Of The Best Books I‚Äôve Ever Read
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2024
Body: I read quite a bit for recreation, but never have I connected with a story and characters quite like this one. The prose is beautiful, the character development of each individual character is top tier. I‚Äôve never finished a book and been touched as deeply as I felt after finishing Hello Beautiful. This one probably rates as my favorite book of all time, or at least that‚Äôs where it‚Äôs at a few weeks after finishing it. Onto another one of her novels, Dead Edward.

Title: The Heart of Family Life
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2024
Body: I can't think of a novel which has so deeply involved me in the lives, experiences and feelings of it's central characters.  I'm quite sad that I've just finished it, because I don't want to say goodbye to William and the close knit family of four sisters he married into.  My own spare childhood resembles William's.  Yet this novel is a way of seeing what it might be like to be raised in an exuberant, complicated, loving family... and how it evolves over time, as each girl becomes her own self... and William comes to realize that he matters.What impresses me most about the writing of Ann Napolitano is her ability to go to the heart of the matter.  She allows us to see the inner lives of her characters, their aspirations, self-doubts, determination, losses and joys.  There is grace here... saving grace.Perhaps I'm particulary drawn to a work like this because, as child psychologist, I've spent years studying how childhood experiences influence who we become, and the healing that is sometimes needed when those experiences have been less than ideal.  Napolitano shows here how it's often the people closest to us, who care about us, who facilitate our healing.  What the author has created here feels firmly based in reality and the challenges human beings face, and, thankfully, she draws these characters to unexpected reconciliation.

Title: When it gets right down to it, aren't most stories about family?
Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2024
Body: A withdrawn man raised by parents who never saw him meets a girl from a family of girls who see--or think they see everything about him‚Äîand each other. But they are mistaken.His girl tells him they will marry. She tells him he will be a professor. He starts to study. She tells him it's time for a baby. By the time the baby becomes her focus, he realizes he loves her favorite sister. He doesn't want to teach. He wants to work with the basketball team, the only people who ever truly saw him, and cared about him. And because he never knew parental love, he is afraid to be a parent.Read one of the best family stories I've ever enjoyed in Hello Beautiful. See how deftly the author draws her characters and allows you to see them by their actions from several points of view so that you learn their emotions and motivations layer by layer. By the end, you understand and forgive.Forgiveness‚Äîand the lack thereof‚Äî is big in this novel. Having been banished by my mother from my family for several years, I was drawn deeply to the mother who stubbornly kept alive her anger against one of her children for so much longer than mine did. The same woman never forgave her husband for not being the man she expected him to be. She never understood that he was so much more.If you had a family, you understand that families‚Äîeven loving families‚Äîare complicated. Families with problems are even more so. Each person adds his or her own characteristics, talents, opinions, and prejudices to a simmering pot of emotions, misunderstandings, and love. With every stir, the recipe can either boil over or settle into what it was meant to be. It's maybe how we get Forrest's box of chocolates‚Äîyou never know what you're gonna get.Read Hello Beautiful and see that what you thought, or what you were told, or what you expected of someone, is not necessarily the way the story all will turn out. Life is always a surprise at every turn. Why would we expect a book to turn out the way we wish it would? The curveball element makes life‚Äîand books‚Äîall the more worthwhile.

Title: heart wrenching but beautiful story
Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2024
Body: What a wonderful story of 4 sisters and how their different personalities are interwoven among themselves and their family. I fell in love with the characters and all their flaws. The love is bountiful and often painful. I thought it was well written.

Title: I needed tissues for the last 5%
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2024
Body: This is a beautiful book about family and love for dear people no matter what their perceived flaws or foibles.  It‚Äôs about birth and death and the many ways one can deal with each.  It‚Äôs also a book about time and how perceptions change over time.

Title: I‚Äôm mad at Oprah.
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2024
Body: I feel like I was duped by Oprah into reading this book. It starts out OK. But the book is told from four peoples perspectives, and the writer repeats things that they just told you from another person‚Äòs perspective. And not only that things that could‚Äôve been a paragraph for four pages long.  This book is 400 pages it probably could have been 300 pages. Also, there are things that were just not believable. William‚Äòs little sister dies after having a cough for six days? (Not a spoiler this happens in the first two pages.) The parents never speak of her again but they apparently watch home movies of her.  The mother/grandmother is mad and not speaking to one daughter for years but then proceeds to brag about her to the granddaughter? It was so long and boring.

Title: Boring and depressing
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2024
Body: I bought this for a book club and had a very tough time getting into it. It‚Äôs quite boring and some of the characters are quite in likable yet we have chapters devoted to their perspective. It‚Äôs very depressing, so after a little more than half way I gave up. I can‚Äôt remember the last book I didn‚Äôt finish. This is one I regret picking up.

Title: Come on now...
Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2023
Body: Do some reviewers see the name "oprah" and automatically become entralled?  When I started this book, I was in love with it.  After a period of "beach reads", this was refreshing.  The characters seemed well-drawn, and the writing was good.  As the book progressed, the characters no longer made sense.  I don't want to say too much and give away the plot.  Let's just say that the author would add new character traits whose only purpose seemed to be that she needed to make the book longer- and boy, did the book seem looong! These traits were not consistent with the character nor did they add complexity.  The motivations of the characters made no sense to me.  The book became so boring and bogged down in the characters' nonsensical thoughts and feelings, that I considered giving it up,,,but hey...after all, it IS an OPRAH book.  There had to be more to it. Right?  It must be one whopper of an ending...but no.  It wasn't.  It just wasn't a good book.

Title: Hello Beautiful Not Worth Your Valuable Time
Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 7, 2023
Body: I really wanted to like Ann Neapolitan‚Äôs book, Hello Beautiful. My thirty- something daughters loved it. I, however, found the story of the sisters, their mother and William, the boyfriend/ husband to be very off putting. The sisters seem to be in such lock-step that I found their relationships to be unhealthy. Not beautiful at all. They are mothered by a woman who when widowed shuts one daughter and granddaughter completely out of her life for decades, and without a thought has little contact with the other three. William wanders around in a daze and constantly needs rescuing by 1. The sisters 2. Julia. 3. Sylvie and 4. Alice, the daughter he gave up without much thought as an infant. When tragedy occurs all of the characters gallop back to Pilsen ( a real Chicago suburb!) and without much discussion forgive one another‚Äôs rather grave transgressions.This story simply doesn‚Äôt touch the hearts and minds of the struggles it takes to be a fully formed forgiving, compassionate, yet sometimes failure of a family.Another Oprah miss.

Title: The Most Disappointing Book of the Year
Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2023
Body: I know many of the readers will think I am out of my mind.....Hello, Beautiful was like a plane trying to take off ......but just couldn't get airborne.  I love a good read, authors like Isabelle Allende and Barbara Kingsolver consistently meet my expectations. We trust those reviews and believe others' perceptions but perhaps we should question the procedure to determine that a book is worthy of being reviewed with 5 stars, or because Oprah or Reese loved it!  This book seemed to just drift along, with shallow characters, and no surprising plot twists or page-turners. I finished it last night and it left me so dissatisfied and wary about choosing "Best Sellers".  I discussed it yesterday at my book club and it will be interesting to see if any of the other readers concur. I usually do research on a book and author before ordering...this time I didn't.

Title: disappointed
Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2024
Body: After all the reviews I thought this was going to a page turner.  Unfortunately getting though this book felt like molasses.  So slow.  I also prefer some dialogue but for first 300 pages barely had any.  Sorry just didn‚Äôt enjoy anything about this book.

Title: Novela de ficci√≥n
Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2023
Body: La trama es simple y parecida a mujercitas adaptada a nuevos tiempos pasados de los 80 a los presentes.En general me pareci√≥ repetitiva con frases y record√°ndote momentos pasados en la novela que te hacia aun mas pesada la lectura.Me pareci√≥ a una novela rosa.

Title: I really tried to like this book.
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2024
Body: I really wanted to like this book based on all the great reviews.  The story was a good one, but it just was drawn out.

Title: not my fave
Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2023
Body: My main issue with this novel is how out of sorts the characters are. They make choices especially early in that negate something we learned about them earlier. Additionally, when authors explain their ideas to the reader it‚Äôs insulting. We can see the symbolism and the connections. I did not love the exposition. Not my favorite. Just a little too sentimental for me.

Title: I beg to differ
Date: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2023
Body: I'm going to have to disagree with the thrust of the reviews here for Hello Beautiful. I had to power through it. The author appears unable to introduce either wit or subtlety to the characters, with the possible exception of Rose, who is as thorny as her name suggests, and who is the one character through whose eyes I would have liked to have seen parts of the book told. Though disagreeable, Rose at least had some perspective on her children. Alas it was not to be. And then there's the author's need to explain, over and over, her characters' motivations rather than trust that her writing could show the reader. Not a few words could have been saved by letting the characters' actions do the explaining. In the end there's little for the reader to do but power through because the author has trusted us with no other role.

Reviewer: diana jaycox (my friends call me DJ)
Title: It improves as you read further...
Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2023
Body: Hello Beautiful by Ann Napolitano, an Oprah's Book Club selection was read by this reviewer as part of a challenge. It would not have been my choice otherwise. As a rule I read to escape and find that many of contemporary bestsellers require me to be too much in the now and too much in my head. So it was no surprise that I struggled to get into this novel. It was too achingly real! The characters, their lives, their dreams and their struggles collided with my own and made me want to withdraw into my own darkness. I so wanted to send this book to the trash bin. Though, as a writer I challenged myself to read other writers ,especially those that are bestsellers. I needed to discover what makes other authors so appealing. How do other writers set-up their stories, build their settings, develop their characters. After a break, I came back to Hello Beautiful and read this as a writer as well as a reader.  By applying a critiquing approach, I was able to achieve a degree of separation from the story. It was just enough to allow me to focus on the cadence of Ann Napolitano's words, to savor the style of her storytelling and to not get caught in my own angst and issues.I began to see how Hello Beautiful shared so many elements with one of my all time favorite books , Little Women. I was intrigued by the depth of personality of each of the sisters Ann Napolitano created. Ann was able to show how each sister was a part of the others yet completely individuals. How they became who they were was beautifully and intricately choreographed by Ann Napolitano throughout the novel. And, adding William a lost soul, an outsider to the mix, was a brilliant catalyst  for  the sisters growth and development!This was NOT an easy book to read. I  took several breaks but always came back.  This poignant story about family love and relationships, did end up stirring my heart and soul in ways, I admit, prefer to avoid.  At times, I felt like I was on an emotional roller coaster.  By the time I reached the climax of the story I was fully invested in the characters and their lives, the many highs and lows they experienced and yet were able to weather because they had each other. I don't know how many other of Ann Napolitano's my tortured soul will be able to tolerate. I can say that the beauty of Ann Napolitano carefully crafted words, the images she brought to my mind's eye and the powerful feelings of love that seemed to leap from the pages of Hello Beautiful, eventually brought me to place of peace. I read the last page with a sigh. Then I closed my eyes and reflected on all my best memories of life in a large, obnoxiously in your face , flawed, loving family! All the highs and lows, the good times, the bad and the big loving mess of it all!SIGH.

Title: Beautifully written, pretty dreary
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2024
Body: The writing is beautiful. The character development is on point, which is good, because it is a character-driven story. The reader gets to know the characters really well, and the author allows her characters to have flaws - almost to the point of being unlikable.I‚Äôm in a ‚Äúit‚Äôs not you, it‚Äôs me‚Äù relationship with this book, because it was pretty perfect. But it was too much reality than I needed right now. I found it to be relentlessly hopeless. Absolutely a good book if you need a good cry, and you will cry, multiple times.

Title: Life is Complicated
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2024
Body: Every family has stories that of bonds that draw them together and those that pull them apart.  This one was particularly well written and I loved all of the Padavano with their strengths and flaws.  Their journey from childhood through middle age made it hard to put the book down.  Good discussion of depression and impact of family dynamics early in a child‚Äôs life.  It is a good book for anyone looking to read about real family life, both the good and the bad.

Title: Great family story
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2024
Body: Loved this book! Loved the character development! It made you want to keep reading. Lots of twists and turns. I highly recommend this book

Title: character driven family story
Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2024
Body: I liked Hello Beautiful for its well developed characters and story of family dynamics

Title: Worth reading
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2024
Body: What I didn't like about the book is the excessive use of reflective emphasis when dialogue would have been welcomed. There was too much repetition about the inner mental workings of each character. It became tedious. Still, I'm glad I read it.hi

Title: Family Drama
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2024
Body: It was a well written book which made it an easy read. I liked the book but didn't love it. Some things made me mad but they were true to life. The good thing it shows is a strong family bond.

Title: thought provoking
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2024
Body: Hmm i can‚Äôt say i liked the book as a whole, or the story line, but there were so many good thoughts, quotes, life lessons.  It was rich with real life experiences.

Title: Hard to get into but good
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2024
Body: I give the book a three due to it dragged out a lot at the beginning. But after reading the whole book, I now give it a 4All in all it‚Äôs a good read.

Title: family drama
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2024
Body: This is a novel of the 4 Padavano sisters, from childhood to adulthood.  As a William Waters gets to know their many facets, and layers, we learn of his childhood and see him through adulthood.  The interpersonal relationships are complicated, as in any family.The book is a good read.  I enjoyed the storyline in its complexity, but found it redundant in sections and felt it dragged on in some parts.  Still worth the read, however. Character development was carried out with only some of the characters.  I would have like to get to know a couple of other characters.

Title: Beautifully written‚Ä¶
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2024
Body: I love this story about the four Padavano sisters and their parents. Rose is the strong willed matriarch of the family. She strongly believes her husband, Charlie, just doesn‚Äôt quite measure up to what he could have been. Together, they have four daughters. Readers are drawn right into this story and feel every emotion the characters experience. Julie, the eldest of the four sisters, is a planner, a fixer, a girl who knows what she wants and knows how to get it. She has a plan for her life and it doesn‚Äôt include living in a tiny house like where she was raised. Second daughter is quiet Sylvie, a reader who has worked in the public library since she was thirteen and sneaks kisses from the boys behind the shelves knowing she doesn‚Äôt want a boyfriend. She doesn‚Äôt  take the boys seriously because she is just practicing for her one true love. The twins who are energetic, fun loving girls, round out the Padavano sisters. Then there is William a loner, ignored and never loved at home, socially awkward, always wondering where he fits in, how should he behave, and why he wasn‚Äôt enough for his parents. He only feels at home on the basketball court. Julie has decided William is just what she needs to get her life plan started. In alternating chapters, the four main characters tell their story with each chapter bearing the character‚Äôs name. Quoting Walt Whitman‚Äôs poetry and making comparisons of the four sisters to the sisters in Little Women by Alcott, this book is more than a family saga. This book is a love story. It is about acceptance, heartbreak, forgiveness, and understanding.  Napolitano‚Äôs writing is thoughtful and beautiful. The story is deeply moving as each character grows and discover his or her truth and learns how powerful it is to live an authentic life. A five star read and on my list of favorite books in 2024!

Reviewer: diana jaycox (my friends call me DJ)

Title: Hello beautiful
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2024
Body: It's not very often that I cry reading a book but this book was so beautifully written I could feel the sadness, the love, everyone's emotions, and I was moved to tears. What a beautiful and sometimes sad story but well worth every word!

Title: so well done!
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2024
Body: Such an amazing story about how real families love and feud.  I loved the perspective of each character that carried the story forward.  I also loved the intrinsic bonds that bind a family regardless of decades and perceived wrongs.

Title: Disappointed ---characters simply not authentic
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2023
Body: I bought hardcover & Kindle editions on day of release after seeing Oprah rave about it on CBS. What I appreciate most with Oprah's fiction picks is the selections tend to be a cut above (i.e. more literature) than morning show or other celeb book clubs. (I esp enjoyed Oprah's early picks back in late 90s.) I'm sad to report this was a big miss for me. Having been raised with 4 sisters in blue-collar Chicago, I thought it'd be a slam dunk, but I went from being underwhelmed to disappointed to annoyed. Pains me to write a mediocre review as author likely poured her heart and soul into it, but imo this book needed another year editing and revising, as this just wasn't there yet. A few specifics:* I applaud author for attempting to give characters depth & complexity but she violated basic rule of show, don't tell. Too much of the characters' personalities were explained with excess exposition but not SHOWN to readers through actions or dialogue.* While I don't adhere that authors should write only what they know, it was obvious to me early on the author didn't grow up with sisters, nor grow up or spend years in Pilsen or blue-collar Chicago. Neither felt authentic. Felt more as if author was on outside observing or imagining versus having lived it. I can overlook some tells, but the more those slips/omissions/errors add up, the more a reader loses faith in the entire story.*William's upbringing also didn't ring true. I can understand grief-stricken parents emotionally absent in a child's life, but not to the degree explained (not shown) in the book. More development and examples were needed, as parents cannot simply ignore a child--they still need to nurse, feed, cloth and shelter, etc. It's easy to tell but author needed to again SHOW us how cold parents can be there, but not present.* On plus side, the story & writing comes most alive to me with passages on basketball--the relationships, the tempo, the love of the game, the history. Here's where the author did her homework and really did a nice job translating it, esp to female readership (not to sound sexist, as I'm a woman who played basketball in her youth but still learned a few things or two and appreciated the insights she brought.)I'll leave it there as I don't mean to tear down a book that's not horrible, just not great. Possibly my disappointment is greater than most because I came up with high expectations and this just wasn't credible for me. As other reviewers noted, it's not a bad beach read, but not literature and not Oprah-caliber.  (Sorry for any typos--please don't review my review lol.)

Title: delightful
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2024
Body: To read about and get to know the characters who comprise a large and encompassing Italian family and their friends. This book can renew your faith in humankind and will- at the end, put a smile on your face.

Title: Beautifully written, pretty dreary
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2024
Body: The writing is beautiful. The character development is on point, which is good, because it is a character-driven story. The reader gets to know the characters really well, and the author allows her characters to have flaws - almost to the point of being unlikable.I‚Äôm in a ‚Äúit‚Äôs not you, it‚Äôs me‚Äù relationship with this book, because it was pretty perfect. But it was too much reality than I needed right now. I found it to be relentlessly hopeless. Absolutely a good book if you need a good cry, and you will cry, multiple times.

Title: A.story of family
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2024
Body: Ann Napolitano knows how to weave a story , but even more impressive is her ability to make you love her characters.  She develops them so completely, you think you know them, their motivations, and what they will think and do next.  The title is very accurate, as each character is beautiful through the eyes of those who love them.  Highly recommend!!

Title: One Of The Best Books I‚Äôve Ever Read
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2024
Body: I read quite a bit for recreation, but never have I connected with a story and characters quite like this one. The prose is beautiful, the character development of each individual character is top tier. I‚Äôve never finished a book and been touched as deeply as I felt after finishing Hello Beautiful. This one probably rates as my favorite book of all time, or at least that‚Äôs where it‚Äôs at a few weeks after finishing it. Onto another one of her novels, Dead Edward.

Title: The Heart of Family Life
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2024
Body: I can't think of a novel which has so deeply involved me in the lives, experiences and feelings of it's central characters.  I'm quite sad that I've just finished it, because I don't want to say goodbye to William and the close knit family of four sisters he married into.  My own spare childhood resembles William's.  Yet this novel is a way of seeing what it might be like to be raised in an exuberant, complicated, loving family... and how it evolves over time, as each girl becomes her own self... and William comes to realize that he matters.What impresses me most about the writing of Ann Napolitano is her ability to go to the heart of the matter.  She allows us to see the inner lives of her characters, their aspirations, self-doubts, determination, losses and joys.  There is grace here... saving grace.Perhaps I'm particulary drawn to a work like this because, as child psychologist, I've spent years studying how childhood experiences influence who we become, and the healing that is sometimes needed when those experiences have been less than ideal.  Napolitano shows here how it's often the people closest to us, who care about us, who facilitate our healing.  What the author has created here feels firmly based in reality and the challenges human beings face, and, thankfully, she draws these characters to unexpected reconciliation.

Title: Hope
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2024
Body: This family will remind readers that there is hope in relationships that seem hopeless.  Opinions generated about characters change with each chapter.  Well worth the time to read.

Title: Heartwarming
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2024
Body: In the beginning it took me time to want to continue to read but I think my turning point was when Julia made these plans for her life and others and felt compelled to be in charge of everything. This book had everything from loss,grief,love,attempted suicide, lies, honesty, and clarity. It really was riveting and really had me feeling things that was relatable. It is never too late to make connections or forgive.

Title: thought provoking
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2024
Body: Hmm i can‚Äôt say i liked the book as a whole, or the story line, but there were so many good thoughts, quotes, life lessons.  It was rich with real life experiences.

Title: so many tears.
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2024
Body: I think I‚Äôve given one other 5 star rating in my life. This book was beautiful, whole, + everything I‚Äôve ever wanted in a book.

Title: Hard to get into but good
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2024
Body: I give the book a three due to it dragged out a lot at the beginning. But after reading the whole book, I now give it a 4All in all it‚Äôs a good read.

Title: Read for Book Club
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2024
Body: Interesting but not an easy read for me and most likely would not have read on my own.

Title: Families like this one I know.
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2024
Body: Growing up with three sisters and one brother I can so relate to this book. It is a difficult story of pain, loss and reconciliation but well written and intriguing enough to capture the reader.  It takes us deep into the characters personal transformations and historical celebrations and it surprises you occasionally. I enjoyed it and would recommend it.

Title: A slow paced read, but heartwarming overall
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2024
Body: This book is not a page turner by any means. I found myself a little bored at time while reading. The overall story line kept me engaged and I enjoyed reading it overall.

Title: One of the best books I‚Äôve read
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2024
Body: I loved the story of these four sisters and how fiercely they loved each other!  It did remind me of ‚ÄúLittle Women‚Äù, especially with all the sobbing it caused me to do. I highly recommend it!

Title: When it gets right down to it, aren't most stories about family?
Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2024
Body: A withdrawn man raised by parents who never saw him meets a girl from a family of girls who see--or think they see everything about him‚Äîand each other. But they are mistaken.His girl tells him they will marry. She tells him he will be a professor. He starts to study. She tells him it's time for a baby. By the time the baby becomes her focus, he realizes he loves her favorite sister. He doesn't want to teach. He wants to work with the basketball team, the only people who ever truly saw him, and cared about him. And because he never knew parental love, he is afraid to be a parent.Read one of the best family stories I've ever enjoyed in Hello Beautiful. See how deftly the author draws her characters and allows you to see them by their actions from several points of view so that you learn their emotions and motivations layer by layer. By the end, you understand and forgive.Forgiveness‚Äîand the lack thereof‚Äî is big in this novel. Having been banished by my mother from my family for several years, I was drawn deeply to the mother who stubbornly kept alive her anger against one of her children for so much longer than mine did. The same woman never forgave her husband for not being the man she expected him to be. She never understood that he was so much more.If you had a family, you understand that families‚Äîeven loving families‚Äîare complicated. Families with problems are even more so. Each person adds his or her own characteristics, talents, opinions, and prejudices to a simmering pot of emotions, misunderstandings, and love. With every stir, the recipe can either boil over or settle into what it was meant to be. It's maybe how we get Forrest's box of chocolates‚Äîyou never know what you're gonna get.Read Hello Beautiful and see that what you thought, or what you were told, or what you expected of someone, is not necessarily the way the story all will turn out. Life is always a surprise at every turn. Why would we expect a book to turn out the way we wish it would? The curveball element makes life‚Äîand books‚Äîall the more worthwhile.

Title: heart wrenching but beautiful story
Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2024
Body: What a wonderful story of 4 sisters and how their different personalities are interwoven among themselves and their family. I fell in love with the characters and all their flaws. The love is bountiful and often painful. I thought it was well written.

Title: I needed tissues for the last 5%
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2024
Body: This is a beautiful book about family and love for dear people no matter what their perceived flaws or foibles.  It‚Äôs about birth and death and the many ways one can deal with each.  It‚Äôs also a book about time and how perceptions change over time.

Title: Fabulous
Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2024
Body: You will think about this book long after you have read it! It is thought provoking and it will cause you to look for and try to find what are the dysfunctions in your own family.

Title: A ‚Äúreal‚Äù tale of life
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2024
Body: A thoughtful look at the fragile nature of life & love through the lens of a family. A family with four sisters growing up with love, heartache, dysfunction & normal ups & downs on the roller coaster ride we call life. Very relatable to all.

Title: Life is Complicated
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2024
Body: Every family has stories that of bonds that draw them together and those that pull them apart.  This one was particularly well written and I loved all of the Padavano with their strengths and flaws.  Their journey from childhood through middle age made it hard to put the book down.  Good discussion of depression and impact of family dynamics early in a child‚Äôs life.  It is a good book for anyone looking to read about real family life, both the good and the bad.

Title: Great family story
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2024
Body: Loved this book! Loved the character development! It made you want to keep reading. Lots of twists and turns. I highly recommend this book

Title: character driven family story
Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2024
Body: I liked Hello Beautiful for its well developed characters and story of family dynamics

Title: Worth reading
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2024
Body: What I didn't like about the book is the excessive use of reflective emphasis when dialogue would have been welcomed. There was too much repetition about the inner mental workings of each character. It became tedious. Still, I'm glad I read it.hi

Title: Family Drama
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2024
Body: It was a well written book which made it an easy read. I liked the book but didn't love it. Some things made me mad but they were true to life. The good thing it shows is a strong family bond.

Title: Confusing
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2024
Body: This story was hard to follow with so many characters and different plot lines. Not an enjoyable read.

Title: Not bad but not that good
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2024
Body: Could have gotten it done in a lot less pages. Could have been written better.

Title: Beware reader. Hell awaits.
Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2023
Body: For a well respected author to lead the reader into a well researched(he wrote G-d instead of God for the Jews here, an observant Jew would not write god‚Äôs name), into a hell for one blameless character and the trusting reader is a betrayal of faith. We all are aware of tragedy in life and today‚Äôs news is evidence thereof. There is nothing to learn from senseless pain. Perhaps, shine some light on distant hope.

Title: Over rated
Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2023
Body: This book was hard to read in many ways. Hard to keep track of the multitude of characters, hard to understand the slang and timbre of the dialogue, and hard on one‚Äôs psyche as this sad, often violent, story progressed.

Title: Lots of stuff I did not understand
Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2023
Body: It was a lot of Jewish customs and thing I did not know about or understand. No, it was not educational because nothing was explained. I got about half way through and gave up!

Title: A challenge to start
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2024
Body: Too many random story lines

Title: Damaged Product
Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2024
Body: Delivery packaging arrived good and intact - book cover and book spine horribly torn

Title: not sure why, but I like this book
Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2024
Body: Eventually, everything turned out to be just fine.  Lots of people in it.  Entry to the black and Jewish experiences in the 30s.

Title: Too Hard to Follow
Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2024
Body: Too many names and characters to follow.  I lost interest quickly and gave it to the thrift shop.

Title: I tried really hard to get involved in this read...
Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2023
Body: While there were some well developed characters and an interesting storyline, I had a hard time wanting to read on. Knowing it had such high reviews I figured it must pick up but sadly I just couldn't love this book.  I did finish it and was glad once it was done.

Title: Great Read!
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2024
Body: Thoroughly enjoyed the book.  Well written and vivid story about the life and struggles of the blacks as well as the immigrants that came and shaped America.  Heart warming to see that there is much good and kindness in people, unfortunately mixed in with evil.

Title: Pottstown, PA and immigrants
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2024
Body: A story about the Black and Jewish communities in working class Pennsylvania prior to WW II.  Chronicles the tough lives and treatment of these two minority groups.Somewhat reinforces age old stereotypes but manages to highlight the good things that existed during this time.  A good read but does not have longing for a sequel.

Title: Melting Pot
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2024
Body: Tough read but also had so many human, lovely people. Showed through interesting characters the development of a community through the wide range of immigrants / cultures that come together.

Title: Resolving differences
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2024
Body: Interesting involvement of the Jews and African Americans in the 1930s.  A little suspense as to the body found in the well. Loose ends tied up too quickly.

Title: Complex Novel
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2024
Body: I am glad I read this book, as it had a lot to offer and think about. However, I am not a fan of this author's writing style. He uses long, long sentences which although gramatically correct, were annoying.  I thought the book dragged at the beginning, but picked up in the second section and held my interest.Some parts of the book were and sweet and heartwarming  and other parts were too intense for my liking. Also, there a LOT of characters in this book, but I did think the cultural differences examined,  helped shape deeper understanding of people.

Title: I hung in there!
Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2024
Body: This book was slow starting for me and I almost put it aside several times. But I hung in there and finished it. What a beautiful ending! Well worth the struggle to arrive at such a heart wrenching ending!All of the characters and their nationalities were a bit confusing but The descriptions of the characters were so lifelike that I pictured them in my mind and how they walked and talked.One thing I noticed, over and over, was Mr McBrides use of compound sentences. At first I thought the sentences and descriptions were run-on, but as I would reread them, they were very much grammatically in order. Just a little quirk of mine but to me it was noticeable.The description and interaction between Dodo and Monkey Pants was my favorite part. The finger touching competition was so little-boyish!And beautiful!Highly recommend this book - hang in there if you become overwhelmed with characters and the roles they play. It‚Äôs all worth it in the glorious end!

Title: like me some McBride
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2024
Body: Mostly brilliant, only occasionally drifting into modern, critical riffs. Enjoyed the mingling of narratives: newly arrived Jews in Pennsylvania, the seeds of the Klan, the capacity of love and compassion to transcend wide expanses of difference.

Title: interesting story
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2024
Body: I had a hard time getting through parts of this book because it jumped around a lot.  The story wasn‚Äôt always easy to follow.  The ending made it worth reading.I did enjoy the characters in this book.  Read this if you want to learn more about how the blacks and Jewish tolerated each other, both living in close proximity to each other and just starting out.  Both groups wanting to have enough to live and more if they could but the disparities are real.

Title: Interesting story with multiracial components from the 1839s.
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2024
Body: Interesting but a little stretched to link all the elements. It dies keep your interest. Gives some insight into race and religion interaction in that era.

Title: A different navigation through what it was like
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2024
Body: This book was a lesson to me in Jewish culture‚Ä¶a mixing pot of cultures and races.  Set in the 1930‚Äôs, a poor town, with lively characters and mystery.

Title: Everyone needs a Monkey Pants
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2024
Body: Though thought provoking, the book takes a while to settle into its story. Truly grabs the attention of the reader about half way through the book, so patience is needed. I hung in there and truly enjoyed the second half!

Title: a very interesting book
Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2024
Body: I loved the diversity of the characters. I learned of how jewish immigrants and blacks lived side by side in Pottstown - for the most part peacefully. They were from different worlds but their poor lot in life made them comrades of sorts. It was the whites that worked tirelessly to keep these people down. But regardless of their struggles, they had deep friendships and great loves like all people dream of.This was a good book. Most of it about the lives of these people and how they fared. And, how saving some resulted in finally achieving a better life - and forever love.

Title: McBride
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2024
Body: Well written.

Title: Worth the time
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 29, 2024
Body: If you can hang in through the first 1/3, you‚Äôll end up loving this twisting and bumpy and surprising and heartbreaking tale of people. All kinds of people- with all kinds of stories and it‚Äôs just beautiful. And messy. And worth the read.

Title: Heartfelt story
Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2023
Body: This book starts out as a mystery but morphs into a story about neighbors and community in an immigrant and black neighborhood.  Chicken Hill was where Moshe and Chiba Ludlow ran the Heaven and Earth Grocery Store. They lived and worked there among blacks and European immigrants. When the state came looking for a deaf black child to put him into an institution, the residents banded together to keep the boy safe.I enjoyed this book. It was inventive and uplifting. The characters are original and complex. There are so many backstories to each side character that it becomes complicated to keep track of all of them.  I felt like the plot sometimes got lost in all the backstories.  If you enjoy historical fiction and an original story this book is for you!

Title: Book club recommendation
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2024
Body: This was one of the book club reads that I just couldn't get into.  My rule of thumb is 100 pages and I just made it to 45.  There are tons of positive reviews though so maybe that means more.

Title: worth it
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2024
Body: The first 3/4s of this book are pleasant, but not much is happening. In the remaining pages, however, all the threads come together. Worth it to enjoy the pros and the set up.

Title: Enjoyed
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2024
Body: We read this The Heaven and Earth Grocery Store for my book group.  The characters were enjoyable (I especially liked Shonna) and the plot had a lot of twists and turns, which made it interesting, but also a bit difficult to put together the pieces and keep track of events and see connections in places.  The issues that it dealt with made for an interesting book group discussion.  The author did a good job of enriching the story with insights from multiple cultures and subcultures.  I liked it, but didn't love it.  Enjoyable.

Title: Not very good
Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2023
Body: I did not find most of the characters in this book very interesting or sympathetic. I think I did find weird things like Africa-Americans hearing the drums of their ancestors on the Amazon. The Amazon? And loose ends like . . . SPOILER ALERT: Near the middle of the book a piece of paper with a presumably important message on it is never read and is lost; it's mentioned at least once more but never read nor found nor is its significance explained. The end is implausible. How did Nate, carrying a man, get out of the tunnel and make a train within minutes? And did Nate really leave an innocent man to explain a dead body? This is not a very good book, but might have been with better editing

Title: McBride covers the ethnic bases with affection and authenticity.
Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2024
Body: A melange of ethnic biases shown with humor and love in Pottstown, PA, at an earlier time.The characters are vivid and relatable; dialogue is well done.  This fast- paced novel deserves your attention.

Title: Sorry, this book was so boring
Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2024
Body: I read and read waiting to start enjoying this book, as it had a lot of glorious reviews. By 25% into it, I gave up. So many characters I couldn‚Äôt remember who they were anymore. So confusing. I kept trying to figure out the story but nothing grabbed me. There are too many wonderful books out there to waste time with a clunker.

Title: perplexed
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2024
Body: Too wordy, long and confusing., Was recommended by good friend but obviously we have different tastes. Don‚Äôt waste your time.

Title: Such A Disappointment
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2024
Body: It was truly difficult to finish this book. Run on sentences, poor character and plot development‚Ä¶pretty much a waste of my time. I vow to never read another book by this author.

Title: Not My Book of the Year
Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2024
Body: A good editor might have shaped this book into something more coherent. Absent a ruthless red pen, the book rambled and meandered. There were a few compelling characters ‚Äì perhaps Monkey Pants the most memorable ‚Äì but I had trouble keeping the vast cast and numerous plot lines straight.

Title: The Heaven Earth Grocery Story
Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2024
Body: As someone who was born in Pottstown in 1945 some of this seemed contrived.Pottstown was not destroyed by Hurricane Agnes. Only the part south of the Schuykill River.  My father‚Äôs Sunday school class helped people clean up there oil covered houses. BE ACCURATE!

Title: Torn cover
Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2024
Body: Received book on time. It came in same box with second item  Unfortunately, the book jacket was torn  Book was okay but don,t like not having protective cover  combining a book with large cat litter container was not a good idea

Title: Difficult to read
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2024
Body: The dialogue and descriptions change too often.  I was not impressed.

Title: great ending but‚Ä¶.
Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2024
Body: I had a hard time time with this book.  Too many characters and too much detail about them.  I felt it was all over the place until page 290, when it kicked in.  It had a great ending.

Title: Meandering mish mash
Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2024
Body: The book fails to deliver a cogent narrative. Honestly, I got bored and lost among the seemingly endless and unconnected irrelevant details that worked as deviations from what I guess originally may have been an idea for a story.

Title: Great characters, cluttered story
Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2023
Body: This book has so much to like: unique and believable characters, a marvelous setting, multiple poignant story lines and a deep, nuanced understanding of racial and ethnic dynamics. But the story becomes so cluttered that in the end it doesn't work -- at least not for me. I wanted to love it. I'm sad that I could not.

Title: One of the very best books I've read.
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2024
Body: I recommended this for my bookclub because I absolutely loved it. The story is based on the author's ancestry. Everyone in the book club loved it as well. I also recommend viewing the NPR podcast interview of Mr Mcbride. He is a charming and down to earth person!!!PS You can never go wrong with a book by James McBride.

Title: shining star of a book
Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2024
Body: Sometimes i had to stop reading because the fate of characters like Chona and Dodo was so sad.  But by the end the tragedy was lessened and the epilogue left me soothed and uplifted.  I also liked the comic elements, like the cornet band.

Title: Fantastic- So glad I read this book.
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2024
Body: After finishing the first chapter I was unsure if I wanted to keep reading, so glad I did. In a very short time I was completely enveloped in the town and the main characters.Wrapped within the story are so many stark truths about life, love and injustice. I leave these book striving to be kinder and more aware of the struggles around me.

Title: Thanks for Heaven and Earth
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2024
Body: This was a great story.  I enjoyed all the characters. Each with their own ideas about how to survive their lives on chicken hill .. I found it so interesting how just a few people.quietly did their thing, and looked beyond color, or creed, just to be human beingsWell done. Mr.McBride.

Title: You know its good when 2 days later you're still there.
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2024
Body: I loved the detailed in depth character development for everyone. I feel like I know them, could pick them each out in the grocery or on the street. There were so many little gems of cultural depth and timeless philosophy in a rich historic context. I bookmarked more spots to revisit than I ever have before.

Title: The Ending Beauty
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2024
Body: This novel had everything.  The unique characters, their  mind blowing back stories, the unusual reactions to each other kept you turning pages.  The story line may take place during the 20th century, but it's relevant to the 21st.Read Mr McBride's novel, it's worth your time.Goldie

Title: Great story
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2024
Body: I enjoyed the story of  the tough life back in the 1920s for much of the Jewish and black Americans.  And how through love and cooperation a young boys life was saved.  It is different than most of the books I have read lately and was an inspiration.  I recommend it to all who have compassion for their fellow man.

Title: A True Masterpiece
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2024
Body: This novel had me from the first page.  The style , dialogue and story took me on an amazing journey.  I had no personal frame of reference for the events in this story but I was totally engrossed at every twist and turn.  I will long remember many of these characters.

Title: Great Reading!
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2024
Body: Yarn about a mixed black & Jewish community living on the fringe of a predominately white Pennsylvania town in the 1930s. Draws you in and keeps you turning the pages to see what happens next. Reminded me of a Charles Dickens novel woven together with many characters who show up, seemingly play their role and go away only to reappear later on to tie something together. Masterful story telling. Wonderfully enjoyable read.

Title: Rich Lives
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2024
Body: The grocery store is the center of everyone‚Äôs life and though they were each poor financially they were rich with friends, family.
